statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: LSU 66, Arkansas 63 (OT)
article.story: BATON ROUGE, La. (AP) -- At 6-foot-9, 310 pounds, Glen Davis doesn't expect to do a lot of shot blocking. He had two of them Wednesday night, including a crucial one in overtime to help LSU beat Arkansas 66-63. "I can't jump that high," said Davis who scored six points and the only field goal in overtime. "But I felt like he didn't see me so I was like, `I'm going to try to get this one.' I got it and then we scored. It was a big block for me." It was the second straight overtime victory for LSU (9-5, 2-1 Southeastern Conference). The Tigers beat Ohio State in double overtime Saturday. Except for Davis' basket, neither team could score from the field in overtime. Arkansas made 5 of 9 free throws. LSU made 6 of 7 free throws, four of them by Davis, who had 26 points and 18 rebounds. LSU took a 64-61 lead on Davis' basket with 1:01 left in overtime. Eric Ferguson made a pair of free throws with 19 seconds remaining to pull the Razorbacks within one at 64-63. With five seconds left, Davis blocked a shot by Ferguson and Tack Minor rebounded it for LSU. Arkansas fouled and Minor made both free throws to ice the victory. "We don't usually practice free throws," Bass said. "But we practiced them the last two days and it paid off. You have to get those." LSU made 17 of 20 free throws, Arkansas had 11 of 19. "I feel for my players because they really responded so well from our last game," said Arkansas coach Stan Heath. "They shot 53 percent and got good shots. They could have gotten better shots, but the difference in the game is that our commitment to free-throw shooting has got to rise. We have to emphasize to our guys that that's such an important part of the game." The loss was the fourth in a row for Arkansas (13-5, 1-4). Arkansas is 1-18 in SEC road games under Heath. It's the league's worst mark in that time and includes 12 consecutive losses. Brandon Bass scored 15 points for LSU. Arkansas was led by Ronnie Brewer with 17 points. Jones had 15 points and Olu Famutimi scored 13. The Razorbacks made 8 of 17 3-point attempts. Famutimi was 3-for-3 and Jones hit 3 of 7. A steal and a dunk by Bass with 11:28 left put the Tigers ahead by seven, 40-33. But Arkansas came back, 16-4 run, fueled by four 3-point baskets to take a 49-44 lead at the 7:33 mark. The Razorbacks went up 54-49 but LSU scored four straight points, including a 3-pointer by Antonio Hudson who rebounded an Arkansas shot blocked by Bass. The Tigers tied it at 56 when Davis grabbed a rebound and jammed it in with 46 seconds left. Arkansas had two shots but couldn't make a basket. On the second attempt Davis blocked the shot, rebounded the ball and passed it to Hudson, who took it the length of the court to score with 10 seconds remaining. The Razorbacks inbounded the ball with five seconds left, got it to Jones who launched a basket. It was scored as a 3-pointer, giving Arkansas a 59-58 lead and sending the LSU bench and fans into a frenzy. After looking at the replay the basket was declared a 2-pointer, tying the game at 58 and sending it into overtime. "It's tough, but you've got to move on," Jones said. "The refs made that call, you have to expect that. I really can't say how I fee. We had them down. We had them on the ropes and we thought we could pull it out." Arkansas, which was outrebounded in all four earlier league games, was outrebounded 42-29 by LSU. Arkansas went scoreless for over seven minutes in the first half, allowing LSU to take a 22-10 lead. The Razorbacks outscored LSU 16-8 down the stretch and trailed 30-26 at the break.
